docs.title: Medical Reference Wiki
docs.text: Welcome to the clinical reference guide for healthcare professionals.

docs.title: How to Use This Wiki
docs.text:
• Use the search function to find specific conditions
  • Click on disease names to see detailed information
  • Follow treatment algorithms and diagnostic flowcharts
  • Check references for latest guidelines

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
To add or update content: 1. Navigate to the relevant file 2. Click the pencil icon to edit 3. Make your changes 4. Add a commit message describing changes 5. Click "Commit changes"

The site will automatically update within 2-3 minutes.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: COPD is a preventable and treatable disease characterized by persistent respiratory symptoms and airflow limitation due to airway and/or alveolar abnormalities, usually caused by significant exposure to noxious particles or gases.

docs.title: Key Information
docs.text:
• ICD-10 Code: J44.1 (COPD with acute exacerbation), J44.0 (COPD with acute lower respiratory infection)
  • Prevalence: ~16 million diagnosed in US, estimated 30 million affected
  • Age of Onset: Typically >40 years with 20+ pack-year smoking history
  • Leading Cause: Tobacco smoke (85-90% of cases)

docs.title: Pathophysiology
docs.text:
• Chronic Bronchitis: Mucus hypersecretion, airway inflammation
  • Emphysema: Alveolar destruction, loss of elastic recoil
  • Small Airway Disease: Airway narrowing, increased resistance
  • Systemic Inflammation: Cardiovascular and musculoskeletal effects

docs.title: Symptoms
docs.text:
• Progressive dyspnea: Initially on exertion, eventually at rest
  • Chronic cough: Often productive, worse in mornings
  • Sputum production: Clear to purulent
  • Wheezing: Especially during exacerbations
  • Chest tightness
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss (advanced disease)

docs.title: Physical Findings
docs.text:
• Inspection: Barrel chest, pursed-lip breathing, use of accessory muscles
  • Palpation: Decreased tactile fremitus
  • Percussion: Hyperresonance, decreased diaphragmatic excursion
  • Auscultation: Decreased breath sounds, prolonged expiration, wheezes, rhonchi

docs.title: Spirometry (Essential for Diagnosis)
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Clinical Suspicion of COPD] --> B[Post-bronchodilator Spirometry]
    B --> C{FEV1/FVC Ratio}
    C -->|≥0.70| D[Normal - Consider Other Diagnoses]
    C -->|<0.70| E[COPD Confirmed]

    E --> F{FEV1 % Predicted}
    F -->|≥80%| G[GOLD 1 - Mild]
    F -->|50-79%| H[GOLD 2 - Moderate]
    F -->|30-49%| I[GOLD 3 - Severe]
    F -->|<30%| J[GOLD 4 - Very Severe]

docs.title: Additional Testing
docs.text:
• Chest X-ray: Rule out other pathology, assess hyperinflation
  • CT Chest: If surgical evaluation needed, assess emphysema distribution
  • Arterial Blood Gas: If severe disease or acute exacerbation
  • Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Level: If early onset or family history
  • 6-Minute Walk Test: Assess functional capacity

docs.title: COPD Assessment Test (CAT)
docs.text:
• Standardized questionnaire (0-40 points)
  • Assesses impact on daily life
  • <10: Low impact, 10-20: Medium impact, 21-30: High impact, >30: Very high impact

docs.title: Treatment Algorithm
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Confirmed COPD] --> B[All Patients: Smoking Cessation<br/>Vaccinations, Pulmonary Rehab]
    B --> C{Symptoms/Exacerbation Risk}

    C -->|Group A<br/>Low symptoms<br/>Low risk| D[Bronchodilator PRN<br/>SABA or SAMA]
    C -->|Group B<br/>High symptoms<br/>Low risk| E[Long-acting Bronchodilator<br/>LABA or LAMA]
    C -->|Group C<br/>Low symptoms<br/>High risk| F[LAMA]
    C -->|Group D<br/>High symptoms<br/>High risk| G[LAMA + LABA]

    E --> H{Adequate Response?}
    F --> I{Adequate Response?}
    G --> J{Adequate Response?}

    H -->|No| K[Add LAMA]
    I -->|No| L[Add LABA]
    J -->|No| M{Eosinophils ≥300?}

    M -->|Yes| N[Add ICS]
    M -->|No| O[Consider Roflumilast<br/>or Azithromycin]

docs.title: Smoking Cessation (Most Important)
docs.text:
• Counseling: Brief intervention at every visit
  • Pharmacotherapy:
  • Nicotine replacement therapy
  • Bupropion: 150mg twice daily
  • Varenicline: 0.5mg daily × 3 days, then 0.5mg twice daily × 4 days, then 1mg twice daily
  • Behavioral Support: Quitlines, support groups

docs.title: Pulmonary Rehabilitation
docs.text:
• Exercise Training: Aerobic and strength training
  • Education: Disease management, inhaler technique
  • Nutritional Counseling
  • Psychosocial Support
  • Duration: 6-8 weeks minimum

docs.title: Vaccinations
docs.text:
• Influenza: Annual vaccination
  • Pneumococcal: PPSV23 and PCV13 per guidelines
  • COVID-19: Per current recommendations

docs.title: Short-Acting Bronchodilators (Rescue)
docs.text:
• SABA: Albuterol 2-4 puffs every 4-6 hours PRN
  • SAMA: Ipratropium 2-4 puffs every 6 hours PRN

docs.title: Long-Acting Bronchodilators
docs.text:
LABA (Long-Acting Beta Agonists) - Formoterol: 12 mcg twice daily - Salmeterol: 50 mcg twice daily - Indacaterol: 75 mcg daily

LAMA (Long-Acting Muscarinic Antagonists) - Tiotropium: 18 mcg daily - Umeclidinium: 62.5 mcg daily - Glycopyrronium: 50 mcg daily

Combination LABA/LAMA - Formoterol/Glycopyrronium (Bevespi) - Vilanterol/Umeclidinium (Anoro)

docs.title: Inhaled Corticosteroids (ICS)
docs.text:
• Indications: Eosinophils ≥300, history of asthma, frequent exacerbations
  • Agents: Fluticasone, Budesonide
  • Combinations: ICS/LABA, Triple therapy (ICS/LABA/LAMA)

docs.title: Other Medications
docs.text:
• Roflumilast: 500 mcg daily (severe COPD with chronic bronchitis)
  • Azithromycin: 250 mg daily or 500 mg three times weekly (prevent exacerbations)
  • Oxygen Therapy: If resting SpO2 ≤88% or PaO2 ≤55 mmHg

docs.title: Oxygen Therapy
docs.text:
• Continuous: 15+ hours daily if resting hypoxemia
  • Nocturnal: If sleep-related hypoxemia
  • Exertional: If significant desaturation with activity
  • Target: Maintain SpO2 88-92%

docs.title: Assessment of Severity
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[COPD Exacerbation] --> B{Severity Assessment}
    B -->|Mild| C[Increased symptoms<br/>No change in medications]
    B -->|Moderate| D[Increased symptoms<br/>Requires medication change]
    B -->|Severe| E[Requires hospitalization<br/>or ED visit]

    C --> F[Increase bronchodilator frequency<br/>Monitor closely]
    D --> G[Antibiotics if purulent sputum<br/>Oral corticosteroids<br/>Increase bronchodilators]
    E --> H[Hospital management<br/>IV/Oral steroids<br/>Antibiotics<br/>Oxygen<br/>Consider NIV]

docs.title: Treatment
docs.text:
• Bronchodilators: Increase frequency, add ipratropium/albuterol combination
  • Corticosteroids: Prednisone 40mg daily × 5 days
  • Antibiotics: If purulent sputum or increased dyspnea
  • Azithromycin, doxycycline, amoxicillin-clavulanate
  • Oxygen: Maintain SpO2 88-92%

docs.title: Hospitalization Criteria
docs.text:
• Severe symptoms unresponsive to outpatient treatment
  • New or worsening hypoxemia
  • New or worsening hypercapnia
  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Inability to manage at home

docs.title: Respiratory
docs.text:
• Acute respiratory failure: Hypoxemic or hypercapnic
  • Pneumonia: Increased susceptibility
  • Pneumothorax: Especially with emphysema
  • Pulmonary hypertension: Right heart strain

docs.title: Cardiovascular
docs.text:
• Cor pulmonale: Right-sided heart failure
  • Arrhythmias: Atrial fibrillation, ventricular arrhythmias
  • Increased MI risk: Systemic inflammation

docs.title: Systemic
docs.text:
• Weight loss/Cachexia: Poor prognosis indicator
  • Osteoporosis: Especially with steroid use
  • Depression/Anxiety: Common comorbidities
  • Sleep disorders: Sleep apnea, hypoventilation

docs.title: Prognostic Factors
docs.text:
• FEV1: Lower values indicate worse prognosis
  • Exacerbation frequency: >2 per year increases mortality
  • Exercise capacity: 6-minute walk distance
  • Comorbidities: Cardiovascular disease, cancer
  • BMI: Both low and high BMI associated with worse outcomes

docs.title: Regular Monitoring
docs.text:
• Spirometry: Annually or if symptoms worsen
  • Symptom assessment: CAT score, mMRC dyspnea scale
  • Exacerbation frequency: Track patterns
  • Inhaler technique: Review at each visit
  • Comorbidities: Screen for cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis

docs.title: Related Conditions
docs.text:
• Asthma - Asthma-COPD Overlap (ACO)
  • Heart Failure - Common comorbidity
  • Sleep Apnea - Overlap syndrome
  • Lung Cancer - Shared risk factors
  • Pulmonary Hypertension

docs.title: Key References
docs.text:
• GOLD 2024 Guidelines
  • ATS/ERS COPD Guidelines
  • TORCH Trial
  • ECLIPSE Study

docs.title: Recent Updates
docs.text:
• 2024: Updated GOLD guidelines with revised treatment algorithms
  • 2023: New data on triple therapy efficacy
  • 2022: Updated vaccination recommendations

docs.title: How to Edit This Wiki - Simple Guide
Making Changes to Existing Pages
docs.text:
1. Find the page you want to edit
  2. Navigate to the file in the repository

  3. Example: docs/diabetes-type-2.md

  4. Click the pencil icon (top right of file)

  5. Make your changes

  6. Edit the text directly

  7. Use simple formatting (see below)

  8. Save your changes

  9. Scroll to bottom
  10. Add brief description: "Updated diabetes medication dosages"

  11. Click "Commit changes"

  12. Wait 2-3 minutes - the website updates automatically

docs.title: Adding New Disease Pages
docs.text:
1. Go to the diseases folder: docs/diseases/
  2. Click "Add file" → "Create new file"
  3. Name it: new-disease-name.md
  4. Copy structure from existing disease (like diabetes-type-2.md)
  5. Fill in the information
  6. Commit the file
  7. Update the navigation in mkdocs.yml (ask for help with this)

docs.title: Text Formatting
docs.text:
• **Bold text** makes bold text
  • *Italic text* makes italic text
  • ## Large Heading makes a large heading
  • ### Smaller Heading makes a smaller heading

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Essential hypertension is persistently elevated blood pressure without an identifiable underlying medical cause. It accounts for 90-95% of all hypertension cases.

docs.title: Key Information
docs.text:
• ICD-10 Code: I10 (Essential hypertension)
  • Prevalence: ~45% of US adults
  • Age of Onset: Typically develops gradually over years
  • Risk Factors: Age, family history, obesity, high sodium intake, physical inactivity, excessive alcohol

docs.title: Pathophysiology
docs.text:
• Increased peripheral vascular resistance
  • Enhanced sympathetic nervous system activity
  • Abnormal renal sodium handling
  • Endothelial dysfunction
  • Arterial stiffening with age

docs.title: Symptoms
docs.text:
• Often asymptomatic ("silent killer")
  • Headaches (typically occipital, morning)
  • Dizziness or lightheadedness
  • Nosebleeds (rare, severe cases)
  • Shortness of breath with exertion
  • Chest pain (if cardiac involvement)

docs.title: Physical Findings
docs.text:
• Elevated blood pressure readings
  • Retinal changes (AV nicking, cotton wool spots, papilledema)
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy (PMI displacement)
  • S4 gallop
  • Carotid bruits

docs.title: Blood Pressure Classification (2017 AHA/ACC Guidelines)
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Blood Pressure Reading] --> B{Systolic/Diastolic}
    B -->|<120 and <80| C[Normal]
    B -->|120-129 and <80| D[Elevated]
    B -->|130-139 or 80-89| E[Stage 1 HTN]
    B -->|≥140 or ≥90| F[Stage 2 HTN]
    B -->|>180 or >120| G[Hypertensive Crisis]

    E --> H[Confirm with Home Monitoring]
    F --> I[Confirm with Home Monitoring]
    G --> J[Immediate Evaluation]

docs.title: Initial Workup
docs.text:
• Confirm Diagnosis: Multiple readings, home BP monitoring, 24-hour ambulatory monitoring
  • Laboratory Tests:
  • Basic metabolic panel (electrolytes, creatinine, eGFR)
  • Fasting glucose and HbA1c
  • Lipid profile
  • TSH
  • Urinalysis and urine microalbumin
  • Imaging: ECG, echocardiogram if LVH suspected
  • Assess for Secondary Causes (if indicated)

docs.title: Treatment Algorithm
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Confirmed Hypertension] --> B{Stage 1 HTN<br/>130-139/80-89}
    A --> C{Stage 2 HTN<br/>≥140/90}

    B --> D{ASCVD Risk ≥10%<br/>or High Risk?}
    D -->|Yes| E[Lifestyle + Medication]
    D -->|No| F[Lifestyle Modifications<br/>3-6 months]
    F --> G{BP Goal Achieved?}
    G -->|No| E
    G -->|Yes| H[Continue Lifestyle]

    C --> I[Lifestyle + Medication]

    E --> J[Start ACE-I/ARB or<br/>Thiazide Diuretic]
    I --> K[Start 2 medications<br/>Different classes]

    J --> L{Goal <130/80?}
    K --> L
    L -->|No| M[Add/Adjust Medications]
    L -->|Yes| N[Continue Current Therapy]

    M --> O[Consider Combination:<br/>ACE-I/ARB + Thiazide + CCB]

docs.title: Lifestyle Modifications (First-line for all patients)
docs.text:
• Weight Loss: 5-20 mmHg reduction per 10kg weight loss
  • DASH Diet: 8-14 mmHg reduction
  • High fruits, vegetables, low-fat dairy
  • Reduced saturated fat and total fat
  • Sodium Restriction: <2.3g daily (ideal <1.5g) - 2-8 mmHg reduction
  • Physical Activity: 150 min/week moderate exercise - 4-9 mmHg reduction
  • Alcohol Limitation: ≤2 drinks/day men, ≤1 drink/day women - 2-4 mmHg reduction
  • Smoking Cessation: Improves cardiovascular risk

docs.title: First-Line Agents
docs.text:
1. ACE Inhibitors
  2. Lisinopril: 10-40mg daily
  3. Enalapril: 5-20mg twice daily

  4. Side effects: Dry cough (10%), hyperkalemia, angioedema

  5. Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs)

  6. Losartan: 50-100mg daily
  7. Valsartan: 80-320mg daily

  8. Preferred if ACE-I intolerant

  9. Thiazide/Thiazide-like Diuretics

  10. Hydrochlorothiazide: 25-50mg daily
  11. Chlorthalidone: 12.5-25mg daily (preferred)

  12. Monitor: Electrolytes, kidney function

  13. Calcium Channel Blockers

  14. Amlodipine: 5-10mg daily
  15. Nifedipine XL: 30-90mg daily
  16. Side effects: Peripheral edema, gingival hyperplasia

docs.title: Second-Line Agents
docs.text:
• Beta-blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol (if heart failure, post-MI)
  • Aldosterone Antagonists: Spironolactone (if resistant HTN)

docs.title: Target Blood Pressures
docs.text:
• General Population: <130/80 mmHg
  • Diabetes: <130/80 mmHg
  • CKD: <130/80 mmHg
  • Elderly (>65): <130/80 mmHg if tolerated

docs.title: Acute Complications
docs.text:
• Hypertensive Emergency: BP >180/120 with end-organ damage
  • Hypertensive Urgency: BP >180/120 without end-organ damage

docs.title: Chronic Complications
docs.text:
• Cardiovascular: Coronary artery disease, heart failure, arrhythmias
  • Cerebrovascular: Stroke, transient ischemic attacks
  • Renal: Chronic kidney disease, end-stage renal disease
  • Retinal: Hypertensive retinopathy, vision loss
  • Peripheral Vascular: Peripheral artery disease

docs.title: Pregnancy
docs.text:
• Chronic HTN: Continue safe medications (methyldopa, labetalol, nifedipine)
  • Gestational HTN: Monitor closely, deliver if severe
  • Preeclampsia: Immediate obstetric consultation

docs.title: Diabetes
docs.text:
• Preferred agents: ACE-I or ARB (renoprotective)
  • Target: <130/80 mmHg
  • Monitor kidney function closely

docs.title: Heart Failure
docs.text:
• Preferred agents: ACE-I/ARB + beta-blocker + diuretic
  • Avoid: Non-dihydropyridine CCBs

docs.title: Follow-up Schedule
docs.text:
• Initiation: 2-4 weeks after starting/changing medication
  • Stable: Every 3-6 months
  • Uncontrolled: Monthly until goal achieved

docs.title: Home Blood Pressure Monitoring
docs.text:
• Validated device with appropriate cuff size
  • Take readings same time daily
  • Average multiple readings over 1 week
  • Target: <130/80 mmHg

docs.title: Laboratory Monitoring
docs.text:
• Baseline: Complete metabolic panel
  • Follow-up: Electrolytes and creatinine 2-4 weeks after ACE-I/ARB/diuretic initiation
  • Ongoing: Annual labs if stable

docs.title: Related Conditions
docs.text:
• Type 2 Diabetes - Often coexistent
  • Coronary Artery Disease
  • Heart Failure
  • Chronic Kidney Disease
  • Metabolic Syndrome
